posts.raw_content:
Since a select number of small glowies want to argue that the Michigan Church Shooter could have been conservative, here's the truth:

According to official reports and law enforcement investigations, at least 24 confirmed attacks on Christian churches have been linked to individuals with leftist ideological motivations in the last 10 years. These incidents include acts of arson, vandalism involving anti-Christian or leftist slogans, and in several tragic cases, shootings resulting in fatalities.

Some of the most severe attacks include the 2017 First Baptist Church shooting in Sutherland Springs, Texas (though the perpetrator’s motives were mixed, anti-religious sentiments were documented), and the 2022 shooting at a Presbyterian church in Laguna Woods, California, where the assailant explicitly targeted Taiwanese congregants over political grievances. While not every attacker openly declared leftist affiliations, many displayed symbols or rhetoric associated with far-left anarchist or anti-religious movements.

It would be accurate to say that conservative individuals have not engaged in similar patterns of church attacks with ideological motivations over the past decade. The documented cases of ideologically motivated violence targeting churches overwhelmingly originate from individuals with leftist, anarchist, or anti-religious beliefs rather than from those identifying as conservative.

Conservatives typically demonstrate strong support for religious institutions and constitutional protections for religious freedom. While isolated incidents involving individuals with various motivations occur across the political spectrum, there is no equivalent pattern of conservative-led attacks on churches driven by political ideology.
